The investigator and his collaborators study several important phenomena where the main underlying feature is instability, or extreme sensitivity to measurement errors, imperfections of shape, or load. Three projects, unified by the general idea of instability, are pursued. One of them deals with understanding instabilities in nonlinear elasticity associated with martensitic phase transitions, whereby sharp phase boundaries are observed experimentally. Such phase transitions are responsible for shape memory effects in alloys, and for a giant magnetostrictive effect exhibited by some materials, to name just a few examples. Another project applies new tools to analyze the extreme sensitivity to imperfections of the buckling stress of axially compressed circular cylindrical shells -- an essential structural component in a vast variety of structures, from grain silos to airplanes and space ships. The third project focuses on quantitative understanding of a well-known confluence of rigidity and flexibility -- a seemingly contradictory combination of properties -- of Herglotz functions that are ubiquitous in applications from materials science to nuclear physics. For example, the investigator's research quantifies the uncertainty due to experimental errors in the estimates of complex electromagnetic permittivity, which describes how a material interacts with electromagnetic waves of various frequencies from radio waves through visible light to gamma rays. This project constitutes Ph.D. research of a graduate student working under the investigator's guidance.

The most salient feature in martensitic shape transformations, which in particular is responsible for shape memory effect, is the presence of phase boundaries -- sharp interfaces separating different martensitic variants. Stability of such phase boundaries can be completely characterized in terms of the concept of quasiconvexity. With the understanding that characterization of quasiconvexity is often regarded as unachievable, the investigator and his collaborators focus on eminently computable algebraic conditions of stability of phase boundaries and assess their "strength" through specific examples that show how far off algebraic conditions are from true answers, which could be computed either analytically or numerically. Another project deals with buckling of cylindrical shells -- one of the extensively studied, yet poorly understood problems in mechanics, where the classical formula cannot be used to predict buckling stress observed in experiments due to initial imperfections of load and shape. This project creates a mathematically rigorous theory of the buckling of slender bodies that is capable of explaining why initial imperfections of shape and load have strong influence on the buckling stress in some structures, while having negligible effect in others. The third project studies the somewhat paradoxical behavior of Herglotz functions, that are at the same time extremely rigid and surprisingly flexible. Its understanding contributes to several areas of mathematics and physics and answers many important questions. The problems of data validation, and extrapolation are addressed. This project constitutes Ph.D. research of the investigator's graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Instabilities in materials science" investigated three different
phenomena where instabilities play central role. One of the projects examined
material instabilities that are responsible for shape memory effect and the
giant magnetostrictive effect, for example. Such instabilities occur only in
special materials exhibiting high degree of nonlinearity in their
strain-stress response. When the material is strained beyond a certain
threshold it begins to undergo a phase transformation, whereby new phases
separated by sharp phase boundaries nucleate and grow. The project
investigated a special class of Hadamard materials. For these materials the
threshold strains could be identified exactly when its shear modulus is
sufficiently large. When the shear modulus is very small the material behavior
becomes almost liquid-like. In this case a part of the threshold boundary,
called elastic binodal has been identified. Moreover, the remaining part of
the binodal was shown to require infinite complexity in its energy-minimizing
microstructures. A similar complexity has been observed during the
crystallization process in metals.

Another project examines structural instabilities in elastic
solids. Specifically, buckling of cylindrical shells under axial compression.
This instability is of purely geometric nature, whereby the stress in the
material stays small, while various parts of the structure undergo coordinated
rotations, leading to buckling of all slender structures. The naive asymptotic
analysis predicts a much higher buckling load than is typically observed in
experiments. The main goal of this project was to identify specific
mathematical mechanisms of instability of the buckling load with respect to
perturbations of load and shape. One outcome of the
project is the identification of the boundary layer that must form near the
top and bottom edges of the compressed cylindrical shell. The other is that
this boundary layer alone cannot cause buckling load instability in a
perfectly straight circular shell. Thus, shape imperfections interacting with
the boundary layer must be the cause of the observed
instability. Mathematical understanding of shell buckling is crucial for
estimating structural stability in a vast variety of structures,
from grain silos to airplanes, to space ships.

Three fundamental physical principles: causality, time-invariance, and
passivity are responsible for the ubiquity of Stieltjes functions in physics
and engineering. Stieltjes functions form a special class of complex analytic
functions that describe the response of linear media or devices to external
influences. Examples include complex electromagnetic permittivity, which
describes how a material interacts with electromagnetic waves of various
frequencies from radio waves through visible light to gamma rays; complex
impedance and admittance functions of electric circuits made of resistors,
capacitors and inductive coils; effective conductivity of binary composites;
and scattering S-matrices in high energy physics. The central problem is to
extrapolate such functions form a limited frequency band, where measurements
are available to a larger interval of frequencies. The PI and his PhD student
have developed a theory quantifying the uncertainty of such an extrapolation
when the error with which the values of the function are measured is known.
The results of this project must eventually become an integral part of
software that incorporates measured data and produces physically valid choices
for complex electromagnetic permittivity or complex impedance functions
matching the data. The uncertainty inherent in such extrapolations can range
from small to unacceptable, depending on the context. The developed theory
contributes towards a better understanding of this uncertainty.  This project
also constitutes Ph.D. research of a graduate student Narek Hovsepyan working under
investigator's guidance.
